qas.question: Can a DBMS be transfered to a different DBMS?
Why would someone attempt to unite two different databases?
In order to merge, what must the database maintain?
What are the important parts of the database related application that should be moved?
How can a DBMS database migration be made easier?
What is portable from one DBMS to another?
What kind of database is migration impossible from?

plausible_answers.text: A complex or large database migration

qas.question: What is always an easy and cheap project for an individual?
What no longer exist to help migration between specific DBMSs?

plausible_answers.text: tools to help importing databases from other popular DBMSs

qas.question: What is not typically provided by a DBMS vendor?

context: <b5_0>A database built with one<b5_0/> DBMS is not portable to <a0_0>ano<a0_0/>ther <b6_0>DBMS<b6_0/> (i.e., the other DBMS cannot run it). However, in some situations it is desirable to move, migrate a database from one DBMS to another. The reasons are <a1_0>primarily economical<a1_0/> (different DBMSs may have different total costs of ownership or TCOs), functional, and operational (different DBMSs may have different capabilities). The migration involves the database's transformation from one DBMS type to another. The transformation should maintain (if possible) the <a2_0>database related application<a2_0/> (i.e., all related application programs) intact. Thus, the database's <a3_0>conceptual and external architectural levels<a3_0/> should be maintained in the transformation. It may be desired that also some aspects of the architecture internal level are maintained. <b7_0>A complex or large database migration<b7_0/> may be a complicated and costly (one-time) project by itself, which should be factored into the decision to migrate. This in spite of the fact that <b8_0>tools<b8_0/> may exist to help migration between specific DBMSs. Typically a DBMS <a4_0>vendor provides <b9_0>tools<a4_0/> to help importing databases from other popular DBMSs<b9_0/>.
